metadata.name: Memory Module #184
metadata.description:
Day by day, memories accumulate and shape our dreams, subconscious, ideals, and ultimately, the innermost self. 

This artwork is created by repeatedly drawing squares that are identical in size, with each one representing a memory. As new memories form, the older ones become obscured, fuzzy, or joined with others to form belief structures and intuitions. I hope that this work will remind you of someone, someplace, a song or a melody that‚Äôs important to you. 

Keyboard controls:
[S] Save the current view in live mode.
[1] to [8] Change resolution, 1.5K to 12K.
[G] Toggle paper texture.

URL params:
aspect: custom aspect ratio (?aspect=3).
res: custom resolution multiplier (?res=4).

Made with fractal math and p5js, Memory Module is the first in a 5-part generative art series about introspection. You can read more about the series here: https://elsifthen.github.io/

Created by elsif, 2022.07.

metadata.name: FXHASH Generative Logo #378
metadata.description:
Unique iteration of the first Generative Token minted on fxhash.

It also servers as the actual logo of the platform. It represents the generative processes driving fxhash tokens. Generative Tokens are fed with a unique hash to produce unique outputs based on the hash ‚Äî they are functions with a hash as single input.

The growth that comes out of the text is driven by a "Dividing-Aggregating Walkers" (DAW) algorithm. The hash drives all the DAW settings, as well as a mutation factor which is responsible for changes in each Walker parameters as they divide.

Some iterations will produce very simple outputs whereas others might be more chaotic.

Piece by @ciphrd for fxhash

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #431
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. ‚ÄúThe Bugged Tree‚Äù‚Äôs code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren‚Äôt under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there‚Äôs a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.description:
Unique iteration of the first Generative Token minted on fxhash.

It also servers as the actual logo of the platform. It represents the generative processes driving fxhash tokens. Generative Tokens are fed with a unique hash to produce unique outputs based on the hash ‚Äî they are functions with a hash as single input.

The growth that comes out of the text is driven by a "Dividing-Aggregating Walkers" (DAW) algorithm. The hash drives all the DAW settings, as well as a mutation factor which is responsible for changes in each Walker parameters as they divide.

Some iterations will produce very simple outputs whereas others might be more chaotic.

Piece by @ciphrd for fxhash

metadata.name: Tesseract #386
metadata.description:
'Tesseract' is a generative collection drawing on the concept of the cube from oneirology, the interpretation of dreams. In many mythologies and fields of study, the square is considered a 'perfect shape', thus with its abstraction into three isometric dimensions, the cube is seen by some as a representation of the various aspects of the human condition.

In 'Tesseract', the ribbons flowing between the cubes represent the shared experiences that connect us all. No matter how different our lives might be, we all go through the same joys, sorrows, trials, tribulations and experience attachments of varying degrees. 

It is these experiences that bind us together and make us who we are. With these concepts in mind, viewers are invited to interpret each composition as it relates to them and their unique story, from the perspective of that which has been and that which is yet to be experienced.

Press 'S' to save a high resolution PNG at 2400 x 3396 px.

metadata.name: Cit√©s nuageuses #206
metadata.description:
Un de mes fr√®res s‚Äôest envol√© hier. Ou avant-hier, je ne sais plus. Il a vendu du lest pour sortir une fille. Une bourrasque soudaine les a emport√©s, lui et ses deux tickets de cin√©ma.

Cela fait bien trois semaines que nous n‚Äôavons pas eu de livraison. Pas de courrier non plus, par la m√™me occasion. J‚Äôen re√ßois rarement. Je n‚Äôai jamais re√ßu qu‚Äôune lettre, en r√©alit√©. C‚Äô√©tait une longue lettre √©pistolaire de mon ami Dino. Il est cowboy, dans une cit√© voisine. 

Mon fr√®re connaissait cette fille depuis bien cinq ou six ans. Il √©taient au coll√®ge ensemble. Il y avait encore des livraisons toutes les semaines, √† cette √©poque. Parfois deux fois par semaine. On pouvait vendre des enclumes et acheter du petit lest. Poids pour poids, on y perdait. Mais avec √ßa on arrivait quand m√™me √† vivre.

C‚Äô√©tait le temps o√π les rochers n‚Äô√©taient pas attach√©s. Ils d√©rivaient rarement, le vent n‚Äô√©tait pas si fort. Et ils √©taient plus denses aussi. Aujourd‚Äôhui, un rocher qui n‚Äôest pas en laisse ne sera plus l√† demain.

√Ä l‚Äô√©poque, j‚Äô√©tais moi-m√™me cowboy. Je vivais avec Jacques, un bon copain. Il n‚Äôy avait rien de sexuel entre nous. On gardait les rochers. Un soir, on jouait √† l‚Äôespagnolette, il m‚Äôa relanc√© de trois alors que j‚Äô√©tais atout tr√®fle. Vous imaginez la suite. Je ne l‚Äôai plus jamais revu apr√®s √ßa.

Plus personne ne va au coll√®ge. Mon fr√®re √©tait d‚Äôune des derni√®res g√©n√©rations. Apr√®s √ßa les gens ne voyaient plus l‚Äôint√©r√™t. Tout devient de plus en plus l√©ger, et apprendre √† lire ou √©crire ne p√®se rien. Plus on mine, plus on vends des enclumes, plus on peut acheter du lest. Mais comme le lest est plus cher que les enclumes, √† force, la cit√© devient de moins en moins lourde.

Le vent est de plus en plus fort aussi. Je pense que c‚Äôest pour √ßa qu‚Äôil y a moins de livraisons. Il y a de moins en moins de cit√©s qui arrivent √† rester suspendues. Celle de Dino s‚Äôest envol√©e l‚Äôann√©e derni√®re, Dino avec. Avec moins de cit√©s √† visiter par voyage, les livraisons sont moins rentables.

Avant d‚Äô√™tre cowboy je construisais des ponts. C‚Äôest comme √ßa que j‚Äôai appris √† lier les rochers. Plus personne ne le fait aujourd‚Äôhui. Il faut commencer par ancrer le rocher domestique. Et apr√®s, il faut attendre. C‚Äôest la partie la plus difficile. Personne n‚Äôa appris √† suffisamment attendre. Parce que plus le temps passe, plus on devient l√©gers. Mais c‚Äôest le plus important. Il faut attendre le que rocher sauvage devienne suffisamment l√©ger. Sinon, il emportera le rocher domestique avec lui et on aura tout perdu.

Je me demande pourquoi il a achet√© ces deux tickets de cin√©ma. C‚Äôest toujours le m√™me film qui passe. Je ne l‚Äôai jamais vu. √áa parle de dialectique et de ma√ßonnerie, il para√Æt. Le cin√©ma c‚Äôest un domaine que je trouve trop contraignant. Encore une id√©e de bureaucrate. Places assign√©es. Horaires fixes. Un processus administratif au profit de la structure sociale. Classique. Les bureaucrates commencent toujours par nous exploiter et ils finissent par nous ali√©ner. ‚ÄúServir le peuple‚Äù, ils appellent √ßa. 

Cela fait des ann√©es que le pont est de moins en moins solide. De toutes les fa√ßons, on n‚Äôa rien pour le r√©parer. Nos rochers sont domestiqu√©s depuis le temps, mais ils s‚Äôentrainent les uns les autres au lieu de se stabiliser. La suspension des cit√©s, √ßa a l‚Äôair simple mais √ßa ne l‚Äôest pas vraiment. Quand elles ont √©t√© construites, avec les machines-outils des livreurs, elles √©taient bien suspendues. Mais peu √† peu, elles se sont d√©grad√©es. La seule richesse des cit√©s, c‚Äôest leur gravit√©. Pourquoi r√©parer ce qui est destin√© √† s‚Äôenvoler ?

Je comprends pourquoi mon fr√®re a vendu du lest. Apr√®s tout, le lest est l√† pour √™tre vendu tant qu‚Äôil vaut encore quelque chose. Jeudi dernier, le pont est tomb√©. Notre deuxi√®me rocher majeur est toujours reli√© par la chaine des rochers mineurs, mais elle ne va pas tenir longtemps. La cit√© va s‚Äôenvoler bient√¥t. Peut-√™tre demain ou apr√®s-demain. Je vous laisse, je dois aller miner.
